Entry.1:
Final Inspection by our O.C. (Capt. Donovan. Left Liverpool 2 p. m- Parade through Sydney and Reviewed at Domain by Col. Ramaciotti- Spend night at Show Ground.

Jan.15th.
Entry.2:
to Orient Wh’f. Grand farewell- fine spectacle- left Harbour at 1.30 p. 

m- spent good afternoon- slightly ill at night- slept in hammock.

Jan.16th.

Sabbath- pleasant trip- Boxing on board. Victoria sighted at 6 p.m. 

Jan.17th.

Arrived Port Melbourne- correspondence- leave to City of Melbourne- Our impressions- Sargents trip to St. Kilda- Billiards- Pantomime (Mother Goose) Very good- Riot- Return to Osterley.
Entry.3:
Bad news- No Leave- Exceptionally enthusiastic send off by Melbourne people- something

to be grateful for.
Entry.4:
Departure from Port Melbourne- We take up A.M.C duties- self in charge of ward- Canteen and its Irregularities

Jan.20th.

Continuous good weather- Instructions by Capt. Smith Osier- fractures & bandages. Correspondence.
Entry.5: Arrived Outer Harbour (Adelaide) - fine jetty (?) Leave of 3 hours- Miss Mc. Donald & Miss Bray, Left for Fremantle 6 p.m.
Entry.6:
One week on water- Life-belt parade- Instruction- Sydney High Boys- wash clothes.

Jan.23rd.

Sabbath- church parade good weather- spar with Tommy Watson. Letters.

Jan.24th.

A rough day on the ocean- Albany & the Leeuwin- Instruction 
g
 in Hemorrhage.
Entry.7:
Arrived at Fremantle- General Leave to Perth- Impression of the City 

Motor trip through Kings Park- fine sights of River Swan- Australia’s largest Baths- return to Fremantle & "Osterley"- Hearty farewell. "Last man on board & How he got there"- A last, long glimpse of Dear, Old Australia.
Entry.8:
Anniversary Day- The Ghost Walks- Capt. Atkins- Medical Instruction.

Jan.27th.

Second Lecture on Hemorrhage- Prominence of strange fish- Presence of many sharks- Boxing bouts.

Jan.28th.

Heat of tropics- Lecture by Capt. Jenks (R.M.S. Osterley) "Discipline & Morality"- First heats of Boxing Tourneys- F. Beaurepaire, Promoter.

Jan.29th. 

Lifebelt drill- weather much hotter- Ship Inspection by Col. Holland. O.C. of troops- More good boxing- Lecture on Fractures.

Jan.30th.

Sabbath- Rain- Peculiar Tropical weather- Church Parade & Correspondence.
Entry.9:
Rough weather & rain- 2,200 miles from Home.

February- 1916
Entry.10:
Concert by Passengers- a la Tivoli Follies- very popular Entertainment- Speech by Col. Holland. Rough weather.

Feb.2nd. Bad cold- Usual Ward Duties- Weather hot & sultry- Glorious Eastern sun-set – Boxing.
Entry.11:
Fine day- arrival in Harbour of Colombo at 7 a. m- Boat besieged by Natives- Peculiar boats & method of propulsion- Many large boats in Harbour including

Hospital ship- "Karoola" on way to Sydney- Route march through Colombo- Native Barracks- We are greatly pestered by natives- Two Rickshaw rides- Peculiarities of Buildings, People & their Customs- Cheap fruit & drink (Yes! Cheap & nasty!)- Canteen at Barracks. Lemonade. Biscuits. Fruit etc. - Return to Harbour & troopship- Headaches prominent- Impressions of Colombo- fair Boat leaves at 10 p.m. for last stage of voyage.
Entry.12:
The "Briny" once again- The "Tangled Skein" (Orczy.)

Lecture by Returned Nurses on Hospital Duties in Egypt- Semi-finals of Boxing.

Feb.5th.

Issue of "Osterley Keystone" Washing day- Second class Cabins (?) Good weather.

Feb.6th.

Third week of Voyage- Church Parade- Weather rougher- Many sick- Self an abstainer

Feb.7th. 

First land sighted since Colombo- Islands of Socotra & the "Brothers"- Also Cape Guardafui in the Evening- Finals of Boxing.

Feb.8th.

"One Day" (Glyn) - good but hot weather- Rifle & Physical Drill competitions among Infantry- Tug-o’-War won by Artillery- Correspondence

Feb.9th.

Gulf of Aden- Arabian Coast & Islands- Lantern lecture by Capt Jenks – Practice with ships gun- Belt Parade.

Feb.10th.

Pass "Twelve Apostles" Islands Also many vessels. The Red Sea- First & only death on Board- L. H’man- Burial at sea- impressive ceremony.

Feb.11th.

Red Sea coolest part of our Voyage- Preparations- Stewards Concert to troops. Farewell speech by skipper.

Feb.12th.

Gulf of Suez- "Boys pleased at end of Voyage- Hammocks & Blankets handed in

Feb.13th.

Arrived Suez 6 a. m - Impressions of Port & Town- final preparations & disembarkment- Strength of Natives.

Egypt. 1916

Feb.13th.

Last sight of good old Osterley Dry rations- Poor train service from Suez- Pestering by natives begins- Indian sikh who admired Anzacs- Loss of cap. Arrive Zeitoun 1 a.m. Transport of kit to camp Blanket issue- Bed. 2.30 am.

Feb.14th. 

Parade 9 a. m - Address by O.C Again meet Sgt Roberts & other Liverpool friends- Survey of camp- Easy day- First trip to Heliopolis & Cairo- Impression both good & bad- Slums- Natives- Y.M.C.A. 

coinage troubles.
Entry.13:
Parade 6.30 a.m. Abundance of Tomatoes & dough nuts. Raining all day- Cairo. I meet Quinert, Barnes & Smith- Esbekieh Gardens-The Bazaar- Dispatch of Parcels & Cards.

X End of Egyptian Diary.

Diary resumed on
Entry.15:
& March 13th Continued in note form.

Virgins Tree
 (continued):-

Tree 2000 years old- Visitors Books, Drank water from well.

Church

Sanctae Familiae- Fine altar- Valuable ornaments & statues- Magnificant wall paintings.
Entry.18:
Fuite vers L’Egypt.

4. Halteaux Bords du Nil.

5. L’Abre de la Vierge

6. Entrée A Heliopolis

Statues of St Stanislaus, St Antonius & Holy Family. - Belgian Horticulture.

1. 
 Virgins Tree & Marys Well.

Situated two miles from Zeitoun Camp- Remains of Original tree used by Holy Family for shelter- Also well from which Holy Family drew their water. At present worked by Oxen- Photographed against Tree- Souvenirs & Cards

2. 
 The Obelisk
:- 

Two miles from camp- near Matarieh- Composed of one piece solid granite- 60 feet high- covered with hieroglyphics

3. 
Cemetery.

One mile from Zeitoun- Graves hundreds & also thousands of years old- Some graves very shallow with earth & stones covering body- Family tombs- Valuables buried with bodies has lead to destruction and unearthing of graves-
Entry.19:
Egyptians Bazaar.

Description- Articles- Cosmopolitan- Dealings.
Entry.20:
Garry Drive. (Fred & self)

One hour- 10 piastres- Sultan’s Palace- Slums- The Nile- Episode of falling horses- & demand for more money by Arab driver- The Consequence.
Entry.21:
Kursaal.

Revue: "Smile Up- Theatre- "Good"- Not so the Show- Production & setting very faulty- Poor acting & dressing- Songs & dialogue in English & French.

7. Ostrich Farm.

A mile & a half from Camp- built on similar line to native villages- Site of ancient farm- Young & old birds & eggs- Male birds all black- The Lookout- Used by our Signallers- Fine pigeon collection- Egyptian conjuring boy.

The Zoo. The Nile. The Palace. The Citadel- The Pyramids & Sphinx- The Arab Quarters.

8. 
Change of Camp.

Zeitoun to Ferry’s Post:- Left Zeitoun March 5th 1916- Took train to Cairo & thence to Ismailia which is 100 miles from the Capital town- Good train journey- cultivated country- Nile Irrigation scheme- Ismaila a large village- A march of 5 miles chiefl’y on sand & in which we cross Suez Canal brings us to 7th Aust. Fld. Ambulance- Sleep on desert sands under wagon. Very cold- "Ferry Post Camp.

9. 
 Further Change of Camp.
Entry.22:
Ferry Post to Moascar:-

A strenuous march owing to hot weather & amount of luggage- Camp near Railway Line- All hope of joining 1st. Fld. Amb has vanished-

We become attached to
Entry.23:
F. A. – Queenslanders & S. Australians- Good food- O.C. Fair- Plenty of toil- Boys downhearted- Big movement apparent, judging by number of troops in the vicinity of Moascar-

Rumours of going to France- Active Service in reality- Inconvenience of washing etc- Sleeping out- Wet blankets
Entry.24:
Seventh Field Ambulance

Officially attached to Unit- our "14th. of
Entry.25:
boys" in "B" Section under Major Brennan M.C- Impressions of Officers- Strict letter censoring- Announcement of Australians going to France- Issue of Respirators.

Continuation of Diary.

The voyage from Egypt to France.
Entry.26: Inspection by O.C- Break Camp at Moascar- March with full kit to station. Entrain & leave Moascar.
Entry.27: Monotonous train journey to Alexandria- Arrive at Port at 7 am. Embark on A. 41- S.S. Minneapolis- Destination unknown- ship packed with men & horses- Food poor- hammock issued.
Entry.29:
14th

Vessel leaves at 6.30 a. m The Mediterranean- Constant wearing of life-belts because of submarine menace- "Band selections by 25th Batt- Ship’s canteen gives first fair deal for many weeks- Picket duties on horse-decks- Lights out 5.30 p.m.
Entry.30:
Sea much rougher- Consistent rains- Picket duties Minneapolis fitted with two guns- also two Lewis machine guns- "Our troopship the first to leave Egypt for France.

Mar.16th.

Picket duties- Ship Inspection- Band- Letters. Rough & cold weather-
Entry.31: Pass Malta- Hair-cut by Barber who visited our shop in Balmain- Physical drill & Inspection. Calmer.
Entry.32: Pass C. Bon (Algeria) - Also Sth. Coast of Sardinia- Inoculation- arm very bad- Food much worse.
Entry.33:
Pass Island of Corsica

Birthplace of Napoleon- arrive at Marseilles 2.30 pm. Naturally fortified port. Shipping centre of importance- Night spent on board- Sleep on seat 9" wide.
Entry.34:
Unloading of Vessel- deprivation of Camera- arm much better- We are all anxious to get away from vessel.

Egyptian Figures 1 to 10.

Diary while in France.

Mar. 20th.

Left vessel & marched to our encampment- Site of Indian G.H- originally a German residence- fine grounds with abundance of fruit trees & luxuriant vegetation- great contrast with Egypt.

Mar.21st.

Bully-beef & biscuits- Inspection by a French General- Break camp at Marseilles- Baggage guard. Leave by train for unknown destination. Sleep. (or at least try to sleep) on train.

Mar.22nd.

No reveille necessary. Spend all day in train
Entry.35: mile long) – Pass through Lyons. Dijon. Avignon, and other large towns- fine pastures- villages- orchards. farms. vineyards Regularity & beauty of trees & hedges- Apparent absence of all menfolk. Women & girls on farms & in offices- Enthusiastic welcomes by French.
Entry.36:
B & B- Very cold- no sleep- Now in Nth. of France- agricultural country- Souvenirs requested by French-

Monotony broken by beautiful landscapes- Journey completed (58 hours) at 10 p. m- Rejoin baggage guard- Night spent in snow- 6" fall. Village of Thiennes.

Mar.24th.

Guard baggage till noon- A good meal, and How I came by it. - Hospitality- Rejoin Unit in afternoon Australians encamped in or near Morbecque-
Entry.38: Fatigue duties- route march to Hazerbrouch’e- large village. "Café au lait."
Entry.39:
Sabbath- Mass in village church- service in French- underclothing & blanket issue (most acceptable) - rain- "café" again.

Mar. 27th.

Inspection of our 7th. Brigade by General Sir Douglas Haig. C.I.C- village street- Sir Douglas said: - I am very pleased with
Entry.40: Bde and I am sure they will acquit themselves excellently. We move from school to Chateau.
Entry.41:
Billeted in barn over stable

Route march- sick parade- Constant firing of British Artillery plainly heard.
Entry.42: Fatigue- Practical experience in combating gas by means of helmet- Weeping-gas- Col. Dolman’s accident- Mess orderly duties.
Entry.43: Pay-day (45 frs) – busy Estaminets & canteen- Battle evident judging by noise of Artillery.
Entry.44: Early morning march- game of Football- stretcher drill- presence of aircraft.
Entry.45:
Apr.1st.

"Fools day"- no jokes or false alarms- Football & Boxing under Capt. Brownell- lecture by Capt. Hamilton- "Veneral Diseases"- Continued bombardment on British front- Half- holiday (?).
Entry.46: Sabbath- Mass 9 a. m. - Pleasure walk- Issue of two gas respirators- Salmons. Sauce. Pears & Lime juice. No! not issued- Letter-writing- "R.C faith in France."
Entry.47: Sick-parade- Marching Orders- Preparation & Inspection of Kit.
Entry.48: Leave Chateau & join with 7th. Bde- Departure from Morbecque 10.30 am- We pass through Hazerbroucke & other villages- Lunch on the road- March proving strenuous to many. Billeted at 3 p. m in barn at village of Outtersteene (11 m)
Entry.50:
resumed at 10.30 a.m. good weather- bad roads. Oh’, those cobbles! Pass

Through Strazeele. Steenwercke many aeroplanes. First signs of German destruction- Destination reached after travelling 9 miles- Quartered in Hospital or D.S. Formerly a brewery. Occupied for a day & a night by Crown Prince – Fort Rompu.

Apr.6th.

Waggon. Guard 3 am to 6 am- myself in party of 36 bearers- kit, blankets etc.- Observation balloons- Lost!- Found! Arrival at Le Estrade-

Billeted in barn- Improvised sleeping- Leave to Steenwercke in evening.
Entry.51:
Capt. Strachan O.C. of new camp- squad drill & letters Sudden departure in afternoon. Strange to say we ride in cars instead of footing it. "Are we off to the trenches?" (Later) "No!"

Apr.8th.

Our party take up duties in
Entry.52:
Divisional Baths at Erquinghem- Work in drying room- very trying & oppressive- "French friends."

Baths ½ mile from Armentieres- Shelling around our abode.
Entry.53:
Sabbath- Work as usual- First glimpse of "Mad Major- hundreds of shells wasted on him by Fritz- Leave to Armentiers in afternoon

Impressions
Entry.54: Our party leaves baths at noon- arrival at
Entry.55:
F.A base- Dinner "en route. Departure from Base to Le Estrade- Heavy bombardment during night.

Apr.11th.

Report "re" presence of Ger-

man spies- Correspondence- Evening spent in French farm- Eggs. Coffee. Toast. Guard duties against German gas. 9 mths since enlistment.
Entry.56: Eggs & bacon for breakfast (?) Route march with O.C. Lecture on Hemorrhage. First mail received (bon!)
Entry.57: Letters home- Route march & Lecture- Eggs regularly.
Entry.58:
Evacuation of Rest Camp- Long & weary march through mud & rain. Arrival at Base.

Apr.15th.
Entry.59:
mths since departure from Sydney- Route march- Erquinghem

Apr.16th.

Sabbath- Mass at "Bac-St-Maur"- Letters- Y.M.C.A- Gas picket.

Apr.17th.

Happy day- Mail from Home- Gas Picket at night.

Apr.18th.

Gas Picket duties.

Apr.19th.

Self in party of bearers for Bois-Grenier (A D.S) Leave for destination 8 p.m.

Apr.20th.

Our A.D.S. a couple of hundred yards behind reserve trenches. "FIRST DAY" in action- Stretcher bearing in support trenches. Our dug-out comfortable- Part of Line called Shaftesbury Avenue- "Jenolan Caves"- Danger of shells "M’s S"- Action of British Guns. Leave trench at 6 p. m for A.D.S. Great Destruction of village. - no inhabitants- No Red Cross or Brassards. Batteries around our Stations encourages shelling from Fritz.
Entry.60: "Good Friday"- No buns. Plenty of rain- Night duty in trench- 5 p. m- 9 a. m sleep in dug out.
Entry.61: Easter Saturday- quiet day- letters- Night duty at "College Green."
Entry.62:
Easter Sunday proves a bad day for our boys- 250 shells from Fritz in 40 minutes*- Four killed & many wound pass through us- Indescribable wounds- Fortitude of our Boys- Aircraft

*Pozieres comparison.

take advantage of fine weather. Mad Major’s example to his opponents- British pluck & daring in the air.
Entry.63:
Easter Monday- German shelling continues- No. 1 squad duties- Wounded Anzacs.

A Day I shall never forget, also a motor-car run which shall dwell in my memory. Busy night.
Entry.64:
Anzac day- Best wishes to our Brothers- in- Arms – Typical Australian’ as regards weather- Stretcher bearing at College Green.

Return from A.D.S. to Ft. Rompu
Entry.65: Detailed for Hospital Work. I take up my duties-
Entry.67: 28th} Hospital Duties daily from 7 a. m till 7 p. m Sinn Feiners in Dublin.
Entry.69: Plenty of time for correspondence- Aircraft busy- Weather perfect.
Entry.72: Nothing of importance occurred- Great Weather- Artillery active at Ypres.
Entry.73: German trench raid is a success at the expense of our 20th Batt. ("B" Company) Good work- by bearers- We have a very busy night. First hand accounts of courage, humour & fortitude in & after the raid- Casualties number 80 (k & w)
Entry.74:
Relieved in Hospital by "A" section- Mass at 

Bac. St. Maur- French service- Silence of Artillery.
Entry.75: Capt Strachan- "Barbe of Grand Bayou"- A visit to Y.M.C.A- "Lena Ashwell’s No. 2. Firing Line Party" Fine Concert.
Entry.76: Inspection of our quarters by General Birdwood- Impression: - "Perfect"- Wet weather.
Entry.77: Publication of "Australians arrival" in France- Quiet day. Duties as usual.
Entry.79: I witness my first Post Mortem Examination- Capt Culpin performs same. Most interesting operation. Y.M.C.A in Evening
Entry.80: Weather wet & miserable- Artillery silent- Return of some of our "boys" from Bois-Grenier.
Entry.81: Sabbath- Also "Mother’s Day"- Attend Mass- Night duties. Mail- Walk to Croix-du-Bac. Quiet day.
Entry.82: Cool wet weather- A long & needy rest (14 hours sleep) Usual Routine.
Entry.84: A "B" Section Party leaves for Erquinghem- on Engineers Fatigue Duties- Y.M.C.A & Correspondence
Entry.85: "Red Letter Day"- (1) Large mail from Home & friends. (2) I take part in first concert since leaving Sydney- Yours Sincerely "scores well"- Successful show- Incident with our W.O. (L.C)
Entry.86: Self in Party to Bois Grenier. Four miles from Ft. Rompu- British Guns very active near latter part of our march- "Oh! that screeching!"
Entry.87: Change of duties from S.B to Dressing Room- New Friends- "R.B."
Entry.88: Sabbath- Roy develops & prints photo of self at Virgins Tree- "The Village of Bois Grenier"- Activity of Aircraft & Artillery- German bombardment as usual on Sunday.
Entry.89: Having the chance to do our own cooking we live well at Bois-Grenier- I assist with a few wounded cases during the day.
Entry.90: Busier day- Interesting if at times gory work- "Whist." Lt. Porteus’ Death.
Entry.91: "Cribbage"- Few wounded cases- Pathetic incident of Two Brothers (2nd instance)
Entry.92: More cribbage- Many letters- Good news from Home- Still going strong- Plenty of shells from Fritz.
Entry.93:
Busier than usual- "A Gooseberry Picking Expedition" cut short by shell landing 15 to 20 yards from "berry-bush- Luckily a wall between shell & us-

Return to our base at Ft. Rompu.

May.27th 

Duties in dressing room- much more interesting than fatigues. Decline in quality of meals- very busy day- "Uriah Heep"
Entry.94:
Inspection by Generals Porter & Howse & also A.D.M.S- "All well pleased

with state of our "quarters" & dressing-room- Sabbath Church-
Entry.95: Busy-day- Large Mail- Assist in operation by our Colonel & also Capt. Culpin (Brachial artery & two veins severed) - I am admitted to hospital 9 p. m suffering from Influenza.
Entry.96: Ambulance celebrates first Anniversary of leaving S.A. - Patient in Hospital.
Entry.97: Second day in Hospital Much better.
Entry.98:
June 1st.

Discharged from Hospital- Australians inspected at Croix-du-Bac by Messrs. A. Fisher & Wm. Hughes.
Entry.99: Trench & dug-out digging in our paddock- safeguard against German shelling. Parcel despatched to Home. Our friends in P.C. shop – Correspondence. Artillery active.
Entry.100: Trench digging- detailed to bring stretcher case from Erquinghem. Wet w.,
Entry.101: Sabbath- Mass 7.30 am- news of naval engagement- Reported German Victory Easy day.
Entry.102: British Victory off Jutland- Wet & miserable weather- I take part in concert at Y.M.C.A. "Australian Corroboree"-
Entry.103: Pay-day- Another journey to Bois-Grenier for a week- D.R. duties- Fierce & prolonged British bombardment- Aerial activity.
Entry.104: Letters to Australia- Visit to surrounding ruins & gardens- "The Church"- "Suicide Corner"- Fruit & flowers most plentiful- Gooseberries once again. Night duty.
Entry.105: Tragic news of Lord Kitcheners Death- Drowned whilst proceeding to Russia on H.M.S. Hampshire Britains loss- "K of K"- Shrapnel from Fritz.
Entry.107: German guns silent- Truth of Naval Engagement- Air fights & pursuits.
Entry.108: Verdun- Burial of lad from 20th Batt. Routine as usual.
Entry.109: Enemy guns silent- Ypres fighting severe- Artillery- Return to Ft. Rompu- A hasty march under wretched conditions
Entry.111: Russian Success. Issue of Steel Helmets (?) Daylight saving scheme introduced into France.
Entry.112: Has an offensive begun? Fierce Artillery bombardment at Ypres.
Entry.113: Further Russian Success- Fokkers & Taubes- First experience of German Gas"- helmets worn for 25 minutes- "Gas from Ypres.
Entry.115:
Trinity- Sunday- Mass 5.30 a.m. (6.30 a.m. by watch) Artillery silent at Ypres- 2 Taubes brought down at 
Ypres
 Armentieres Departure for A.D.S.
Entry.117: Huns shell Armentieres- Destruction of Church & dwellings- Death of Von Molthe- Few Cases.
Entry.118:
Longest day- (daylight 10 p. m & 2.30 a. m) - I meet a couple of the H. H. Boys.

Gas helmet inspection & drill A lively night- Shells land all round our building but fail to hit it- However the Observation Post next door is wrecked- All but a few of us don steel helmets & leave building for trenches.
Entry.119: Night duty. Gas alert on- We are warned of gas, just as the alarms ring out from trenches- False alarm!
Entry.120: Fritz quieter. Anzacs from Balmain- Food "tres bon
Entry.123: Wounded German prisoners pass through our Base Anzacs trench raid meets with great success.
Entry.127: Preparations for evacuation of Ft. Rompu.
Entry.128:
July 1st.

Departure from "good old Home" 10.30 a. m. Destination, Bailleul- Strenuous March owing to rapid pace & heat of day. Arrive at new quarters- V. tired
Entry.129: Beautiful surroundings- Aircraft in evidence- Filthy state of Hospital etc- News of Big British offensive on Somme- Great Success. Visit to Eddie Cornish- disappointment. Air duel.
Entry.130: Bailleul important military Base. Impressions of Town.
Entry.131: Receipt of large mail- "Silver Wedding"- U.S.A (In. Day) Offensive continues.
Entry.132: "Hyde Park"- "Romeron". Visit Y.M.C.A. also R C. Cathedral. Work as usual.
Entry.133: "Soccer" again. Y.M. & Canteen. Great British successes.
Entry.134: Last day at Bailleul. Preparations for departure.
Entry.135:
Leave for Unknown destination. After 7 kilos we pass through 

Strazeele & then on to Boire, where we spend night in Barn. Fine country (hops, wheat & vineyards)- Church (1626)- Our billet originally in hands of British in a skirmish with Germans who occupied a farm house 700 yards away- Germans driven out- Farmhouse shows signs of the frogs.
Entry.136: Glorious day for second stage of march. Leave Borreal midday- After march of 10 miles, arrive at Ebblinghem. Pass the night in huge paddock.
Entry.137:
Billet very good- During day

A & B sections play football- both codes- A section successful- Soccer 3-2, Rugby 9-6 Great day- good sport- Fresh milk- fresh air fresh everything.
Entry.138: Reveille 4 a. m. Ambulance moves off at 6 a. m. for Wizernes (8 m) & then we entrain. We pass through Calais & Boulogne. Cattle-truck- High expectations in passing through B’ne. Journey ends at 9.p.m. at Saleux Night march which proves to be most strenuous experienced to date. We lose our bearings- Many exhausted. Sleep on road.
Entry.139: Another march (4 miles) - Billeted at Breilly till 5 p. m. - Deoart for Vaux (5 miles) - march of 50 to 60 miles since leaving Ft. Rompu- Billet very poor- Village worse- Four of us spend night on cart.
Entry.141: Large mail from Home. Route march (6 miles) During march we encounter cavalry & M.M. Gun Corps going through training.
Entry.142: Six months since sailing from Sydney. Mail. Easy day.
Entry.143: Sabbath. Lecture on Gas by Major Anderson. Mid-night trip to Amiens (N.Z. Hospital)
